page.title: 16FELBRIGG WOODS
page.content: When Felbrigg Hall was built, the sea could be seen from the windows. The {Great Wood}was planted to protect the Hall from the cold northerly winds. Almost half of the 526-hectare Estate is covered by woodland. 60% is{hard- {wood}(the main types of trees being beech, oak and sweet chestnut), the remainder are conifers. The oldest tree is a 130-year old chestnut. Part of the wood is a{Site of Special {Scientific Interest}because there are rare{fungi}growing on the beech trees. The woodsmen are not allowed to inter- fere with the growth of that part, cut trees or take down fallen branches - the area is left to the wildlife. The leaves which fall in Autumn are also left to rot, producing good soil for the new saplings.
